questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented to the hospital with malaise, pain abdomen, and blood in the stools. On examination, the patient also has foot drop. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, elevated ESR, and negative ANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is polyarteritis nodosa. The presence of foot drop is highly suggestive of mononeuritis multiplex. Mononeuritis multiplex in combination with malaise, pain abdomen, blood in the stools, anemia, elevated ESR, and negative ANCA is highly suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa.

Polyarteritis nodosa is necrotizing arteritis involving medium-sized vessels. It may present insidiously with fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, myalgia, or neuropathy. Mononeuritis multiplex is most commonly seen as a foot drop. Patients also develop symptoms related to vasculitis of a particular organ system. Cutaneous manifestations are skin ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis. Renal involvement is common and manifests as hypertension or renal failure. GI involvement presents as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, bleeding, bowel infarction, and perforation.

There are no specific serologic tests. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, leukocytosis, elevated ESR. Patients with classic polyarteritis nodosa are negative for ANCA. Diagnosis is confirmed only by confirming vasculitis on biopsy.

Other options:

Option B: Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium- and large-sized arteries- usually aortic arch and its branches. It is suspected in a young woman with decreased or absent peripheral pulses, blood pressure discrepancies, and arterial bruits. There is elevated ESR, mild anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. Diagnosis is confirmed with arteriography.

Option C: Cogan's syndrome is characterized by interstitial keratitis and vestibulo-auditory symptoms. Vasculitis of aorta and aortic valve may also be associated.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis is a granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts with glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings include a markedly elevated ESR, mild anemia, leukocytosis, hypergammaglobulinemia, elevated rheumatoid factor. ANCA is usually positive.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with painful lesions on her lower limbs as seen below. Further evaluation shows an association with the HLA -B51 haplotype. What is the characteristic histopathological finding in this patient?

choices.text: Segmental transmural fibrinoid necrosis of the medium sized vessels
Necrotizing granulomas with giant cells and leukocytic infiltrate in medium sized vessels
Neutrophilic predominant infiltrate in a perivascular distribution in small and medium vessels
Luminal thrombosis with micro abscesses in the small sized arteries

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of Behcet's disease which is a small-to-medium vessel neutrophilic vasculitis. The image shows erythema nodosum which is a painful, acute, erythematous eruption that is limited to the extensor aspects of the extremities. Pathological examination of the lesions will show lobular or mixed lobular and septal panniculitis. The histopathological findings will be neutrophilic predominant infiltrate in a perivascular distribution in small and medium vessels.

Behcet's disease:

Behcet disease is associated with HLA haplotype B51 in particular. Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Here (Th17) T helper 17 cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall. There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. The condition is treated with steroids, cyclophosphamide and TNF antagonists.

Histopathology:

  • The classic Behçet lesion is necrotizing leukocytoclastic obliterative perivasculitis and venous thrombosis with lymphocytic infiltration of capillaries, veins, and arteries of all sizes. Cellular infiltration is seen in a perivascular distribution. Neutrophils and CD4+ T lymphocytes are present around the vasa vasorum and perivascular area.
  • The mucocutaneous lesions show the presence of lymphocytic infiltration, Ig, and complement deposition at the dermal-epidermal junction with necrosis and ulcer formation
  • Some papulopustular lesions in Behcet's may show leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgM, IgG, C3, and fibrin deposits. This is consistent with an immune complex vasculitis.
  • Ocular lesions may show leukocyte infiltration around blood vessels, occlusive retinal perivasculitis, and thrombosis. Nongranulomatous panuveitis is characteristic. 
  • Perivascular cuffing of T lymphocytes and monocytes, as well as apoptosis of affected neurons, will be seen in neurological lesions that occur as a result of this condition
  • Renal histology may show mesangial proliferation, proliferative glomerulonephritis, and crescent formation.
  • Arthritis is characterised by synovial inflammation which will show significant neutrophilic inflammation and not as many lymphocytes.

Other options:

Option A: Segmental transmural fibrinoid necrosis of the medium-sized vessels is seen in polyarteritis nodosa and occurs due to immune-complex deposition.

Option B: Necrotizing granulomas with giant cells and leukocytic infiltrate in medium-sized vessels is seen in Wegener's granulomatosis and it is ANCA mediated. 

Option D: Luminal thrombosis with microabscesses in the small-sized arteries is seen in thromboangiitis obliterans.

Note:

Erythema nodosum occurs in various systemic conditions such as Behcet's disease, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, bacterial or deep fungal infection, inflammatory bowel disease, or cancer. It may also occur after the use of certain drugs, including oral contraceptives and antibiotics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a left-sided temporal headache and jaw claudication. She has also recently been having fatigue, malaise, and a mild fever. Gentle pressure on the scalp elicits focal tenderness. ESR is elevated. Diagnosis is made based on a temporal artery biopsy. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of giant cell arteritis. Aortic aneurysms are commonly associated with this condition.

Giant Cell Arteritis - It is an inflammatory disroder of medium to large vessels and occurs due to infiltration of T cells and macrophages.

Clinical features - Constitutional symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and weight loss. Classically, headaches due to GCA are located over the temples. Other findings include jaw claudication, transient/permanent vision loss, and polymyalgia rheumatica which presents as the stiffness of the hips and shoulders. Additionally, large vessel involvement commonly presents as aneurysms of the aorta that may dissect. Large vessels like vertebral artery, aortic artery and ophthalmic artery are affected resulting in aortitis, aortic aneurysm, diplopia and sometimes complete loss of vision. 

Physical exam findings - Diminished pulses and discrepant blood pressure in the arms can occur and the temporal or other cranial arteries can be tender or thickened.

Diagnosis - ESR is generally highly elevated. A temporal artery biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis. Biopsy shows pan-arteritis, often most pronounced in the media, composed of CD4+ lymphocytes and macrophages

Treatment - The mainstay of treatment is glucocorticoids. Oral glucocorticoids may be tried if there is no visual loss but in the presence of visual loss IV glucocorticoid pulses must be administered.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with a right-sided headache for 2 weeks along with jaw pain. It has progressively increased in severity. Of late, she also has a loss of appetite, malaise, and fatigue. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hip, which has disabled her from doing household chores. On examination, the patient appears pale and the temperature is 99.8F. Gentle pressure on the scalp elicits focal tenderness.  ESR is elevated. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis with polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient should be immediately started on steroids. 

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and in people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have signs of superficial temporal artery inflammation, including erythema, pain on palpation, nodularity, thickening, or reduced pulsation on the affected side. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. It is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. 

A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore, patients with a clinical diagnosis of GCA, especially with headaches or visual symptoms should immediately be started on steroids. Else damage may be irreversible if treatment is delayed beyond 48 hours.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by temporal artery biopsy. It may not be positive in all patients, due to patchy involvement of the vessels. Obtaining a biopsy segment of 3-5 cm with serial sectioning may yield a positive result. A color doppler ultrasound can be used as an alternative to temporal artery biopsy. 

Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig).

Other options:

Option A: Sumatriptan is used in the treatment of migraine headaches. Although migraine headaches commonly present with unilateral headache, the other clinical features in this patient are suggestive of GCA.

Option B: There is a limited role of vascular imaging in the diagnosis of GCA. Additionally, the patient must be started on steroids without awaiting diagnostic confirmation when GCA is suspected.

questions.text: The reagent used in the pathergy test is
questions.solution:
The reagent used in the pathergy test is normal saline.

Pathergy test is the nonspecific skin inflammatory reaction to intradermal saline injection. This test is positive in Behcet disease. 

The diagnostic criterion in Behcet's syndrome is the presence of recurrent oral ulcerations plus two of the following:

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions
  • Positive pathergy test

Other options:

Option A- Intradermal injection of killed Bartonella henselae is done in the Foshay test. It is positive in cat scratch disease.

Option B- Metabisulphite is used as a food preservative. It is thought to trigger asthma.

Option C- Purified protein derivative of mycobacterium is used in the tuberculin test. One tuberculin unit is injected intradermally on the flexor aspect of the forearm and a reading is taken after 48h (Mantoux method).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash, and swelling of her hands and feet for the past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Changes in the tongue and hands are as shown in the image.  Which of the following is not a complication of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. The complication not seen in Kawasaki disease is thrombocytopenia.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

Complications include:

  • Coronary artery aneurysms and thrombosis
  • Myocardial infarction due to stenosis of the coronary artery at the site of aneurysm
  • Hydrops of gall bladder
  • Sterile pyuria (urethritis)
  • Arthritis
  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Thrombocytosis (late)
  • Diarrhea
  • Peripheral aneurysms and gangrene.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Conjunctival and oral erythema
  • Blistering, edema of hands and feet
  • Erythema of palms and soles
  • Desquamative rash
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve the coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened tender cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy shows the following. Which among the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are distributed throughout the entire length of the artery
Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation
T cell infiltrates are predominantly CD8+
Fragmentation is seen in external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histology image is suggestive of giant cell/temporal arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

It can affect the following arteries:

  • Superficial temporal artery: Intense facial pain or headache along the course of the artery
  • Ophthalmic arteries: Sudden and permanent diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta: Giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. However, a negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis because the lesions are focally distributed, leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis include:

  • Classic lesions are primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina, leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

The image below shows giant cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation:

 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF therapies are used for treatment.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presents with the findings shown below, which he says occur recurrently. He also has similar lesions on his scrotum and complains of redness and pain in his eyes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this young man with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, as well as eye involvement, is Behcet's syndrome.

Behcet's syndrome is a vasculitic disorder that presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations and ocular involvement. It is a multisystem inflammatory disorder with a known association with HLA B*51. 

This syndrome commonly presents in young people, with males having more severe disease. These patients present with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers that are usually small and painful, painful genital ulcers, skin lesions (folliculitis, erythema nodosum, positive pathergy test, etc.), uveitis, arthritis/arthralgia, deep vein thromboses, etc.

To diagnose a patient with this condition, they must present with recurrent oral ulceration in addition to 2 of the following - genital ulcers/ocular involvement/skin lesions/positive pathergy test.

Topical glucocorticoids can be used to manage oral and skin lesions, but ocular involvement can often only be managed with intravenous steroids, azathioprine, and cyclosporine. 

Other options-

Option (A): Cogan's syndrome characteristically presents with interstitial keratitis and hearing loss. Hence, eye involvement is common, but oral and genital ulceration are not usually seen.

Option (B): Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that occurs due to the infiltration of lymphocytes into exocrine glands. This results in dry eyes and a dry gritty sensation in the mouth. However, recurrent oral and genital ulceration is not a common feature of this disease. 

Option (D): SAPHO syndrome is characterized by synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, and osteitis (SAPHO) and can present with various skin and musculoskeletal manifestations. Oral and genital ulceration is uncommon.

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of anti neutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitides?
  1. Microscopic polyangiitis
  2. Polyarteritis nodosa
  3. Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  4. Henoch-Schonlein vasculitis
  5. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  6. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
questions.solution:
Antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) associated vasculitides include:

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Other ANCA-associated diseases are drug-induced vasculitis and renal limited vasculitis.

Small vessel vasculitides are either ANCA-associated vasculitides or immune complex vasculitides.

  • Immune complex vasculitides can be caused by:
    • Infections: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human Immune deficiency virus (HIV), or endocarditis.
    • Autoimmune conditions such as SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, and Sjögren syndrome. 
    • ANCA-associated vasculitides show little or no immune complex deposition and are known as pauci-immune vasculitides.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) involves upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidney. Symptoms of the upper respiratory tract include bloody nasal discharge, nasal ulceration, sinusitis, and chronic otitis media, characteristic saddle nose deformity due to damage to the nasal cartilage. Symptoms of the lower respiratory tract include lung nodules and alveolar hemorrhage. Renal symptoms include high blood pressure, proteinuria, hematuria and a rapidly progressive renal failure. A c-ANCA pattern with positive anti-PR3 antibodies is seen. Lung biopsy will show evidence of vasculitis and necrotizing granuloma formation, which is characteristic of this disease. Granulomas are absent in the kidney biopsy.

Microscopic polyangiitis causes small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis without granuloma formation. Glomerulonephritis and acute renal failure are the common manifestations. Anti-MPO antibodies positivity with a p-ANCA pattern is seen. Kidney biopsy will show vasculitis of the capillaries without granuloma formation and crescentic glomerulonephritis. Lung involvement is less common.

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome) involves the skin, cardiac and gastrointestinal tract and peripheral nervous system with associated eosinophilia. Biopsy shows necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilic infiltrates and eosinophilic granulomas.

Drug-induced vasculitis may be seen with drugs such as indomethacin, ATT drugs like rifampicin and isoniazid, and anti-hyperthyroid drugs like propylthiouracil, methimazole, carbimazole

The assessment of disease activity includes assessment of inflammatory markers, ANCA antibodies and renal function tests like urea and electrolytes, urine protein quantification, urine microscopy.

Disease activity can be monitored with tools like Birmingham Vasculitis Activity Score (BVAS).

Treatment involves:

  • Induction of remission to avoid or slow down organ involvement by cyclophosphamide in addition to high-dose steroids.
  • Plasma exchange or intravenous rituximab can be used for the same.
  • Rituximab is superior to cyclophosphamide in disease relapse.
  • Maintenance of remission is usually done by either methotrexate or azathioprine.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (frequent sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (hemoptysis), and kidneys (hematuria), and an x-ray shows the presence of a cavity in the right lung. These, along with laboratory features and positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA (cANCA) suggest that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

GPA is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels. Also, necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis is present in the condition.

Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, saddle nose, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present.

Antiproteinase 3-ANCA or antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (cANCA) is seen in 95% of patients and is a useful marker of disease activity.

Management is as follows:

  • Induction with cyclophosphamide and glucocorticoids for severe disease. This is stopped after 3-6 months and can be switched to rituximab, azathioprine, methotrexate, and mycophenolate mofetil for the remission.
  • Induction with rituximab and glucocorticoids is also effective in severe disease.
  • For a non-severe disease, methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil along with glucocorticoids is effective for induction as well as remission.

Other options:

Options A - In Goodpasture's syndrome (pulmonary-renal syndrome), anti-GBM autoantibodies are formed against the glomerular basement membrane. Younger patients present with hemoptysis, fever, dyspnea, and hematuria while older people present with isolated glomerulonephritis.

Option B - Microscopic polyangiitis mainly involves the small arterioles and venules. The presentation is similar to GPA. However, they do not have upper airway disease or pulmonary nodules. They have mainly MPO antibodies or P-ANCA positivity. The distinction can be made on a biopsy where microscopic polyangiitis would have vasculitis without granulomas. 

Option C - Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis that has palpable purpura over the buttocks and lower extremities, arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and glomerulonephritis. It is commonly seen in children and the mechanism is immune complex deposition with IgA antibody.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with complaints of double vision, frequent falls, and numbness of both hands. On examination, the radial pulses were not palpable, but the femoral pulses were palpable. An aortic arch angiogram was done, which revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the aortic angiogram showing areas of stenosis in multiple great vessels arising from the aortic arch is suggestive of Takayasu's arteritis, also known as the pulseless disease.

Takayasu's arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large-sized arteries, in this case, the aortic arch and its branches. Clinical manifestations include vision disturbances and profound weakening of the pulses, especially in the upper extremities. 

Disease pathology is characterized by transmural fibrous thickening of the aorta. The branches of the aortic arch, when involved, are markedly narrowed or even obliterated, causing absent pulses in the upper extremities. 

In some cases, there may also be involvement of other vessels such as the pulmonary, coronary, and renal arteries.

Histopathology:

  • Irregular thickening of the vessel wall is seen with associated intimal hyperplasia. 
  • Characteristic granulomatous inflammation, with the presence of giant cells and patchy medial necrosis.
  • Disease progression is associated with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltrates across all layers of the vessel wall.

Other options:

Option a- Polyarteritis Nodosa is a vasculitis affecting small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It is often seen in renal and visceral vessels, with exception of the pulmonary arteries. Clinical features result from ischemia and infarction of affected tissues and organs.

Option c- Aortic dissection occurs when blood separates the laminar planes of the medial layer to form a blood-filled channel within the aortic wall. The clinical features include sudden onset excruciating pain, which radiates to the back and moves downwards as the dissection progresses.

Shown below are the axial and coronal views of chest CT with IV contrast highlighting a descending aortic dissection:

 

Option d- Kawasaki Disease is an acute, febrile disease seen during infancy and childhood. It usually involves large to medium-sized vessels. Clinical features include conjunctival and oral erythema, blistering, edema of the hands and feet, erythema of the palms and soles, desquamative rash, and cervical lymph node enlargement. It is associated with many cardiovascular sequelae including coronary arteria ectasia and coronary artery aneurysms.

The image shows an aneurysm of left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery due to Kawasaki disease:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and a tingling sensation in his hands and feet. He is hypertensive and investigations reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and fibrinoid necrosis on skin tissue biopsy. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: Can be associated with Hepatitis B

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a hypertensive male with peripheral neuropathy, abdominal pain, bloody stools, and elevated ESR with negative C- ANCA is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa. 30% of patients with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) have chronic hepatitis B and deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes in affected vessels.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the small and medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, mesenteric vessels (including renal), heart, and brain. Pulmonary vessels are usually not involved, however, bronchial vessels may be involved occasionally.

The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, the patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings- Rash, purpura, nodules, cutaneous infarcts, livedo reticularis, Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Musculoskeletal- Arthritis, arthralgia, myalgia
  • Renal artery involvement- hypertension and renal failure.
  • Mesenteric artery involvement- abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and bowel perforation.
  • Nervous system- Peripheral neuropathy, mono-neuritis multiplex, Cerebral vascular accidents
  • Genitourinary- Testicular, ovarian, or epididymal pain

Diagnosis:

  • No specific diagnostic test
  • Elevated leukocyte count, with neutrophil predominance
  • Elevated ESR
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia
  • Hep B and C antibodies
  • Eosinophilia- Rare and if present, suggests the diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg Strauss)
  • Antibodies against myeloperoxidase and proteinase C (ANCA) are negative or rarely found.
  • Biopsies of symptomatic skin lesions, painful testes, nerve or muscle- showing medium vessel vasculitis
  • Angiograms- showing aneurysms of small and medium-sized vessels in the renal, hepatic and visceral vasculature

 The image below shows the histopathological image of an arterial biopsy in PAN.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presented with hemoptysis and reduced urine output. There is no history of asthma or upper airway disease. On evaluation, he is found to be positive for p-ANCA. Renal biopsy showed non-granulomatous inflammation, with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is microscopic polyangiitis.

The above clinical scenario of hemoptysis, reduced urine output, positive p-ANCA antibody, and biopsy showing non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis with few or no immune complexes affecting the small vessels (capillaries, venules, and arterioles). It may have a gradual or acute onset associated with fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. Renal involvement results in glomerulonephritis which results in renal failure. Hemoptysis occurs due to alveolar hemorrhage.

Laboratory investigations show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. Most cases are associated with positive p-ANCA antibodies. Tissue biopsy would reveal non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium and small-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Patients with PAN do not show p-ANCA and c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation associated with luminal thrombosis.

Options B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. These patients show c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

questions.text: All of the following are necrotizing vasculitis except___
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease is a non-necrotizing non-granulomatous inflammation of medium-sized blood vessels.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile multisystemic disease occurring in children less than 5 years of age. Clinical features include cervical lymphadenitis, conjunctival congestion, erythema of the palms, buccal mucosa, and mucosal edema. It can be complicated by the development of coronary artery aneurysms. These aneurysms appear beadlike and thrombosis can also occur.

Other complications are myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial ischemia, and cardiomegaly. It is managed with high-dose intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin for a few weeks to reduce the incidence of coronary complications. Giant coronary artery aneurysms are treated with surgery.

Other options: 

Vasculitis associated with necrotizing inflammation are polyarteritis nodosa, microscopic polyangiitis, Wegener’s granulomatosis, and Churg Strauss syndrome. 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing granulomatous inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries that characteristically affects the renal and visceral arteries. ANCA are rarely found in patients with polyarteritis nodosa.

Churg Strauss syndrome is characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. Anti-myeloperoxidase ANCA antibodies are positive.  

Microscopic polyangiitis affects small and medium-sized arteries with a predilection to involve the capillaries and venules. It is highly associated with ANCA. Treatment consists of methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil and glucocorticoids for non-severe disease.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever, muscle pain, and hemoptysis. Serology showed MPO-ANCA positivity. Laboratory parameters such as ESR and CRP were elevated. A diagnosis of microscopic polyangiitis is suspected. Which among the following is not a feature of the above likely condition?

choices.text: Medium and large arteries are spared

questions.solution:
Granuloma is not a feature of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is a vasculitis typically involving capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is more common in males with an age of onset of around 57 years.

Clinically, patients may complain of fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. They mainly present with glomerulonephritis and in a few cases, hemoptysis may be the presenting feature. Mononeuritis multiplex and cutaneous vasculitis are the other manifestations. 

They are associated with MPO-ANCA or P-ANCA antibodies. ESR and CRP are elevated. Anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis are also present. 

Morphological features include:

  • Fibrinoid necrosis of the media with absent granulomas.
  • Sparing of the medium and large arteries.
  • Fragmented neutrophils in the postcapillary venules lead to leukocytoclastic vasculitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset of severe headache and visual disturbances. Examination reveals tender, palpable temporal arteries. Which of the following additional symptoms is he most likely to have?

choices.text: Pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips
Paresthesias and weakness in the hands and feet

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation with severe headache, visual disturbances, and tender, palpable temporal arteries is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA). Giant cell arteritis often coexists with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), characterized by proximal muscle stiffness and pain, typically affecting the shoulders, hips, and sometimes neck and lower back.

GCA is a systemic vasculitis predominantly affecting medium and large arteries, commonly involving the branches of the carotid artery, including the temporal artery. It is characterized by inflammation that can lead to arterial stenosis or occlusion, causing symptoms such as severe headaches and visual disturbances due to involvement of cranial arteries. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent serious complications like ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to irreversible blindness if untreated.

Giant cell arteritis frequently coexists with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), a related inflammatory condition characterized by proximal muscle stiffness and pain, typically involving the shoulders, hips, and occasionally the neck and lower back. PMR may precede, accompany, or follow the onset of GCA in about 50% of cases, suggesting shared underlying pathogenic mechanisms. Both conditions are more common in individuals over the age of 50

Other options: 

Option A: Facial swelling and erythema are more indicative of conditions like angioedema or allergic reactions and are not typical of GCA or PMR.

Option C: Intermittent claudication, or pain due to insufficient blood flow, is commonly associated with peripheral arterial disease rather than with GCA or PMR.

Option D: Paresthesias and weakness in the hands and feet suggest peripheral neuropathy, which is unrelated to the symptoms of GCA or PMR.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with knee pain, mild nausea, and a nonpruritic rash on his legs following a recent sore throat treated with penicillin. His vital signs are stable, and laboratory tests are unremarkable. What complication is this patient at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation with knee pain, mild nausea, and a nonpruritic rash on his legs, particularly after a recent sore throat treated with penicillin, is indicative of IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schonlein purpura). Intussusception is a common complication in these cases.

IgA vasculitis is characterized by immune complex deposition in small vessels, leading to palpable purpura, arthralgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. A significant complication of IgA vasculitis is intussusception, especially ileo-ileal intussusception, due to submucosal hemorrhage and edema in the bowel wall forming a lead point. Patients with IgA vasculitis should be closely monitored for signs of intussusception, such as abdominal pain and bloody stools, as prompt intervention may be required.

Other options:-

Option B: Adrenal insufficiency, such as in Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome, typically occurs due to adrenal hemorrhage from severe bacterial infections like meningococcal meningitis. This patient lacks the characteristic features of meningococcal meningitis, such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status, making adrenal insufficiency unlikely.

Option C: Thrombocytopenia, particularly immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), often follows viral infections and presents with a purpuric rash. However, ITP usually presents with isolated thrombocytopenia without the arthralgia seen in this patient. Additionally, IgA vasculitis is associated with normal or increased platelet counts, not decreased.

Option D: Anterior uveitis is associated with systemic immune conditions such as juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), which presents with prolonged joint symptoms without a rash. This patient's acute presentation with a rash and recent upper respiratory infection aligns more with IgA vasculitis, which is not associated with anterior uveitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic indicator for cryoglobulinemic vasculitis?

choices.text: Absence of hepatitis C viral infection

questions.solution:
Glomerulonephritis is a poor prognostic indicator in cryoglobulinemic vasculitis because it signifies severe involvement of the kidneys, which can lead to progressive renal damage, chronic kidney disease, or renal failure.

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis involves the deposition of immune complexes in small- to medium-sized blood vessels, causing inflammation and damage. When these deposits affect the glomeruli in the kidneys, it can lead to glomerulonephritis, characterized by proteinuria, hematuria, and decreased renal function.

The presence of glomerulonephritis typically indicates a more aggressive and systemic form of the disease, requiring more intensive immunosuppressive therapy and closer monitoring. Long-term outcomes are worse in patients with renal involvement compared to those with more limited disease manifestations. Acute mortality directly from cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is uncommon, but the presence of glomerulonephritis is a poor prognostic sign for overall outcome. In such patients, 15% progress to end-stage renal disease, with 40% later experiencing fatal cardiovascular disease, infection, or liver failure.

Other Options:

Option A: Lower levels of serum cryoglobulins generally indicate less severe disease activity. High levels of cryoglobulins are associated with more severe disease and systemic involvement. Therefore, low serum cryoglobulin levels are not considered a poor prognostic indicator.

Option B: Cutaneous involvement, such as purpura or skin ulcers, indicates disease activity but is often more limited compared to systemic involvement like glomerulonephritis. While cutaneous vasculitis can cause discomfort and morbidity, it is not associated with the same level of poor prognosis as renal involvement.

Option D: The presence of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is a common underlying cause of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. However, the absence of HCV does not inherently indicate a poor prognosis. Patients without HCV-related cryoglobulinemic vasculitis might have other underlying etiologies, but their prognosis is more influenced by the extent of organ involvement rather than the absence of the virus itself.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of sinusitis, hemoptysis, and joint pain. Physical exam reveals oral ulcers and palpable purpura. Labs show elevated inflammatory markers and a positive ANCA test. Which of the following is the most commonly used treatment regimen in the induction phase of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and positive ANCA test suggest granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). For induction phase in GPA, the most commonly used treatment regimen includes glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) combined with cyclophosphamide.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a systemic autoimmune vasculitis characterized by inflammation of small to medium-sized blood vessels, leading to necrosis and granuloma formation. The treatment approach for GPA typically involves two main phases: induction of remission and maintenance therapy.

During the induction phase, the primary goal is to achieve remission and control active disease manifestations. The cornerstone of induction therapy for GPA involves a combination of glucocorticoids (steroids) and an immunosuppressive agent. Steroids, such as prednisone, are used to rapidly suppress inflammation and alleviate symptoms. Cyclophosphamide, a potent immunosuppressive agent, is often chosen alongside steroids for severe cases or when vital organs are involved. It is given orally or intravenously and helps in controlling the autoimmune response responsible for tissue damage and systemic manifestations.

Once remission is achieved, the maintenance phase aims to prevent disease relapse while minimizing long-term side effects of therapy. In this phase, lower doses of steroids are often used in combination with less toxic immunosuppressive agents like azathioprine. These medications help to sustain remission and reduce the risk of disease flare-ups.

Other options:

Option A: While azathioprine is used in the maintenance phase of GPA treatment to sustain remission and reduce the need for higher doses of steroids, it is not typically used as part of the induction therapy. It is considered less potent compared to cyclophosphamide for controlling active disease.

Option B: Cyclophosphamide is used in the induction phase of GPA treatment due to its potent immunosuppressive effects. However, the combination with steroids (option C) is more specific for achieving remission and controlling active inflammation.

Option D: Steroids + Azathioprine: This combination is used in the maintenance phase of GPA treatment, not in the induction phase. Azathioprine alone is not sufficient for inducing remission in severe cases of GPA and is typically reserved for maintaining disease control after initial induction therapy with steroids and cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: Which of the following is an IL-5 antagonist that is used in Churg-Strauss syndrome?
questions.solution:
Mepolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets interleukin-5 (IL-5), a cytokine involved in the maturation, activation, and survival of eosinophilsm, and can be used in Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), is characterized by systemic vasculitis and eosinophilia. Mepolizumab has been approved for use in EGPA to reduce the frequency of relapses and control asthma exacerbations in patients with refractory disease. By blocking IL-5, mepolizumab reduces eosinophilic inflammation and helps in managing the disease activity associated with EGPA.

Other options:

Option A: Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-4 receptor alpha subunit, thereby inhibiting IL-4 and IL-13 signaling.

Option B: Omalizumab a monoclonal antibody that binds to immunoglobulin E (IgE) and is used in allergic asthma and chronic urticaria. 

Option C: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 receptor antagonist used in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, giant cell arteritis, and cytokine release syndrome.
